p: There are numerous studies confirming the anticancer activity of oleuropein, as observed in human cancer cell lines, such as: breast adenocarcinoma (cell line MCF-7, MDA) [ 83, 84, 85, 86, 87], melanoma (cell line RPMI 7951) [ 86], urinary bladder carcinoma (cell line T-24) [ 86], colorectal adenocarcinoma (cell line HT 29, Caco-2, LoVo) [ 86, 88, 89], prostate cancer (cell line TF1) [ 87], lung carcinoma (cell line A549) [ 90], glioblastoma (cell line LN 18), renal cell adenocarcinoma (cell line 786-O) [ 87], and glioma (cell line U251, A172) [ 91].
